“This occurred because we had such a strong and large construction pipeline,” Cary Bruteig, a researcher with Apartment Insights and author of the apartment association report, told the Post.

Apartment vacancy is the highest since the Great Recession of nearly two decades ago.

Douglas County has the lowest vacancy rate at 5.8 percent, while Denver has the highest at 7.7 percent.

Development

Denver Mayor Mike Johnston has set up a dedicated permitting office for developers, cutting red tape in a city where he said it “was too difficult to build things.”

The mayor’s order, his first since he was elected two years ago, aims to handle start-to-finish  building permits in six months — from a current nine to 10 months, the Denver Business Journal reported.

The order follows similar directives of mayors in San Francisco and Los Angeles, who issued executive orders from tackling homelessness and drugs to whisking approvals for affordable housing to quickly rebuilding homes torched by wildfires.

With the new office run by Jill Jennings Golich, the city’s new permitting czar, every project will get permits within 180 days, from its concept plan to its site development plan to a city granted permit, Johnston said.

Under the new permitting office, if a project is in the city’s hands for more than 180 days, the developer can appeal within 14 days with the executive directors of all seven offices that work on permitting approvals, Johnston said.

Meanwhile, landlords of large office buildings and hospitals in Denver have pushed back against city and state green building rules, saying they damage their bottom lines and the economy.

Complaints from various business sectors have led the city Office of Climate Action, Sustainability and Resiliency to redo its Energize Denver, or plan to cut building pollution, the Denver Post reported.

Commercial - office leasing

Denver’s office market didn’t get off to the best start in 2025.

The total vacancy rate ticked up to 26.8 percent – a 70 basis-point increase from the fourth quarter of 2024 – due to the rise in direct vacancy rate compared to sublease vacancy, which fell 10 basis points, according to a report from CBRE. Compared to the year prior, the total vacancy rate for Denver is up by 170 basis points.

Leasing activity also plunged 16 percent from the quarter before to 1.2 million square feet. However, that figure is 6.6 percent higher than the year before, thanks to government and non-profit tenants inking deals.

Asking rents for office space were relatively stable for the third quarter in a row, according to the report. It inched down by 0.4 percent from the end of 2024 to the first quarter, coming in at $33.81 per square foot. This is 1.7 percent higher than the year before.

The fourth quarter of last year saw an increase of office sales, with 19 deals valued at $277.4 million. But that momentum did not continue into the first quarter, when there were three sales totaling $153.3 million.

Basic Stats:

Population: 2.96 million in the metro area (Denver-Aurora-Lakewood) Politics: Denver has a strong mayor-council system, with a Democrat mayor, Mike Johnston, and a 13-member city council, which has 11 districts and two at-large seats. History: Modern Denver came to be in the 1858 Rocky Mountain gold rush, as settlers took over areas that had been set aside as Cheyanne and Arapaho treaty lands. It was a frontier town and a trading and transit hub. A railroad terminus greatly increased the city’s size and prosperity in the late 19th century; it remains the largest city within 500 miles, so it’s an important center for the western plains region and the Front Range. Energy and mining are still important parts of the economy here (in fact, the area was a hub for nuclear energy in the 1960’s, and a waste storage facility contaminated parts of Denver, particularly in the northwestern corner, which remains a problem today), along with government and defense, among other things. Apartment corporation AIMCO is based here, as are a number of fast-casual restaurant groups. Priciest neighborhoods: In Denver, neighborhoods like Cherry Creek, Belcaro, Country Club and Cherry Hills are going to have your priciest listings. There’s a Four Seasons in Downtown Denver now too. But perhaps the most interesting homes will be a (short) flight away, in ritzy ski towns like Aspen, Breckenridge, Vail, and Telluride.

Residential - sales

Sales of new homes around Las Vegas have slid into a ditch as would-be buyers struggle with record-high prices.

Developers sold 942 new homes in March across Southern Nevada, 10 percent fewer than a year earlier as the typical price jumped 9.6 percent to a record $530,000, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported, citing figures from locally based Home Builders Research.

At the same time, home builders had 810 net sales, or newly signed sales contracts minus cancellations, which plunged 39 percent. New home permits fell 25 percent from a year ago.

The slowdown points to a shrinking pool of buyers who can or want to pay for the higher-priced, newly built homes in or around Las Vegas.

While new home sales slowed in the wake of record prices, sales of previously owned homes in Southern Nevada rose, despite a price uptick. At the same time, available inventory soared.

Buyers inked contracts for 2,140 used single-family homes in March, up 3 percent from a year earlier, according to Las Vegas Realtors.  They paid a median price of $485,000, up 4 percent.

By the end of the month, more than 5,400 homes were on the market, up 63 percent from the same time last year.

Residential - rentals

In the first quarter of the year in Sin City, the average rental rate was $1.58 per square foot, about the same from last year, according to Colliers. However, the commercial real estate firm expects this figure to drop over the year.

More units were on the market than the same time a year ago as well – 1,162. As a result, the monthly asking rent for an apartment fell from $1,473 the year before to $1,461.

However, there are fewer apartments under construction in Las Vegas. As of the first quarter, 4,774 were being built, down from 6,625 a year ago and 5,800 the quarter before.

Residential - luxury

Well-heeled buyers would just as soon settle for a palatial pad in Las Vegas near jingling casinos than a Los Angeles estate near the beach.

Sin City, with its summer mercury topping 120 degrees, is a hotter home market than L.A., the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported, citing a study from Zonda, a new residential construction data firm.

The desert city has become the eighth-most demanding market for luxury home buyers, edging out Boston and nearby Southern California, from Beverly Hills to Malibu.

“The lack of state income taxes and reasonable property tax rates combined with world-class entertainment, sports and dining are a major draw for affluent households,” Sean Fergus, executive director of economic research with Zonda, told the Review-Journal.

The high-income job market in Las Vegas has grown 7.9 percent since 2019, per Zonda.

Development

Developers in landlocked Las Vegas have reaped a bonanza with auction buys of dozens of acres of land from the federal government for a combined $16.5 million.

The Bureau of Land Management listed 10 parcels of land on Energy.net, of which eight — comprising 41.85 acres — sold, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported, citing the BLM.

Combined the purchases work out to $394,265 per acre.

The developers paid more than $1.2 million over fair market value for parcels between 2.5 acres and 25 acres. Two of the largest lots, at 25 acres and 10 acres, didn’t sell.

Funds from the BLM land auction will pay for recreational opportunities and wildland fire reduction, according to the agency. The BLM manages more than 245 million acres of public land, primarily in 12 western states.

Developers in Las Vegas point to a local land crunch, with one builder saying 25,000 acres of land around Las Vegas Valley are available for development, with the region poised to run out of buildable land in as little as seven years, according to the Review-Journal.

Home builders at a Keller Williams’ Meet the Builders panel in March cited challenges to development, including the lack of land, high land costs, record residential real estate prices and high mortgage rates.

Commercial - office leasing

The vacancy rate for Las Vegas’s office sector held somewhat steady in the first quarter compared to the year before, at 12.2 percent, according to CBRE. The vacancy rate in the fourth quarter of 2024 was 12.8 percent.

Vacancy was the lowest in the Southwest submarket, where it came in at 6.7 percent in the first quarter. The Central East submarket recorded the highest vacancy rate of 27.4 percent.

In general, leasing activity has been similar to past years, according to the commercial real estate firm. The average asking rents in the prime Southwest and West markets were relatively stable at $3.01 per square foot and $3.10 per square foot, respectively. The asking rent in the struggling Central East sector also held constant at $2.41 per square foot but below the average for the city for the quarter, $2.63 per square foot.

Las Vegas in the first quarter did not see any new buildings be delivered or break ground – similar to the lack of activity in 2024.

The largest deal inked in the first quarter was TC Group’s sublease of 19,996 square feet of space at 400 Stuart Avenue in Downtown. In the SOuthwest, Deloitte signed on for a 11,929-square-foot expansion at 8474 Rozita Lee Avenue.

Basic Stats:

Population: 2.3 million in the metro area (Las Vegas-Henderson-Paradise) Politics: Vegas has a council-manager model, with six council members, the mayor presiding, and a council-appointed City Manager executing decisions. The current mayor, Carolyn Goodman, is an independent, and the council is four-two Dem-Rep. It’s worth noting that a big chunk of the people who live around Vegas live in unincorporated areas, most of which are governed by Clark County. History: Las Vegas was a total backwater until the 1930s, despite activity in the area from both early pioneers and Mormon settlers. It was officially founded in 1905 as a stopping point for the Union Pacific railroad but didn’t take off until 1931 when, in the same year, construction started on the Hoover Dam and Nevada legalized gambling and instituted more flexible divorce laws. The first casino popped up that year, though the first ones on the Strip wouldn’t materialize until the early 1940’s. The town started to gain notoriety for its nightlife after World War II and attracted attention and investment from organized crime figures like Bugsy Siegel. The population boomed through the 1950’s and ‘60s. The ‘60s and ‘70s saw the opening of some of the most famous resorts, like Caesar’s and the original MGM. The ‘80s saw the first mega-resort, the Mirage, which marked the transition into a wider range of entertainment in Vegas, including live music, shows, art, and food in addition to gaming. When the Bellagio opened in the 1990s it was the most expensive hotel in the world, having cost $1.7 billion. Tourism, gaming, and conventions are the town’s main economic drivers. Priciest neighborhoods: Even the highest rollers don’t live on the Strip. Vegas’ wealthiest residents head for gated communities in nearby Summerlin, like The Ridges and Summit Club, or in areas of Henderson like MacDonald Highlands and Southern Highlands.
